Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Untangling Tropical Diversity: A phylogenetic Analysis of Tritrophic Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Last Modified Date: 12/13/09 Last Modified By: Scott D. Snyder

Abstract
Plants and insects represent the majority of multicellular species on Earth. Most of those species are tropical; yet, most species in the tropics remain undiscovered. The proposed research has three primary goals: 1) discover and describe species of parasitic wasps that attack a very diverse group of plant-feeding flies; 2) discover patterns of host-use by the wasps; and, 3) reconstruct the history of the wasps' diversification (the evolution of many wasp species). To reach these goals, the team of investigators and their students will collect and rear insects, analyze the DNA of immature stages and adults, and analyze physical traits of adults.

This project addresses a major biological question: is diversification mediated by interactions among organisms or is diversification an ecologically neutral process? The project focuses on three groups of economically important organisms: plants related to pumpkins; fruit flies related to major agricultural pests; and wasps that attack the flies and are potentially important for pest control. Undergraduate education is a key component of the project. Undergraduates will be involved in all aspects of the research, including fieldwork in the tropics, molecular data collection and analysis in the laboratory, and communication and dissemination of the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We examined tropical communities consisting of cucurbit plants (pumpkin, squash, and cucumber family), flies that feed on them during their immature stages, and wasps that attack these developing flies. Previous studies demonstrated that the flies were exceptionally diverse, with many species feeding on the reproductive parts of just a few plant species. In this project, we focused on flowers of two species of cucurbit plants and documented extraordinary diversity in the wasps as well. The extent of diversification that we uncovered using new molecular techniques was somewhat unexpected since most wasp species are morphologically indistinguishable. Wasps proved to be extreme host specialists: In nearly all cases, each wasp species successfully attacked only one host fly species on only one plant part on only one host plant species. We developed molecular techniques that enabled us to identify the ecological processes that mediate this diversification, eliminating an alternative hypothesis of ecological neutrality. Our results are broadly applicable to the increasing number of tropical systems showing exceptional levels of cryptic diversity among insects that are morphologically similar but genetically quite distinct. 

 

This study was a collaborative project bringing together in synergistic fashion expertise in tropical ecology, wasp systematics, and molecular systematics techniques from three different primary institutions (Cornell College, Texas A&M University, and USDA/SEL , respectively). Nine undergraduates and one graduate student received extensive training in systematics (including database management and image capture and processing) at Texas A&M under this project. The graduate student and two undergraduates were provided with teaching opportunities to enhance career options and another teaching opportunity was provided to a visiting graduate student from another university. All students developed web pages for various wasp species and their contribution is acknowledged on these pages. The graduate student and six of the undergraduate students have co-authored peer reviewed publications arising from this project. Three of the undergraduate students subsequently entered graduate school, one is currently applying, and two others obtained entomology-related employment upon graduation, facilitated by the work on this project.
